The passage of the National Emergencies: which formalized the process for declaring states of emergencies and granting special powers to the President during those emergencies.
The ability of the President to initiate: typically through an executive order, and the process for terminating an existing state of emergency.
The public discussion and surprise surro: particularly highlighted by President Trump's declaration of a national emergency to secure funding for a border wall.
The confirmation from the Brennan Center: as of February 2019, 58 national emergencies had been declared by various presidents since 1979, with 31 of them still in effect, indicating that every U.S. president since 1976 (excluding Gerald Ford) has declared at least one national emergency.
